(42) 29thConclusions,Minute 4.)The War Cabinet gave further consideration to the Indian)sition in the light of the following : (a) Telegram No. 539 S.^ dated the 6th March, from theViceroy, reporting the views of the Commander-in-Chief. . t(&) Telegrams Nos. 540 S., 545 S. and 549 S. from the Viceroy.(c) A speech by Jawaharlal Nehru, reported in that morning Vnewspapers, to the effect that any promise of reforms atthe end of the war was mere quibbling, and that in theimmediate present a Provisional National Governmentshould be formed, responsible to the Indian people, andnot to the Viceroy or to the British Government.After discussion, the War Cabinet agreed as follows : (1) The India Committee was' invited to prepare a furtherrevise of the draft Declaration.This revision should be carried out on the basis that the Declaration represented His Majesty's Govern-ment's considered scheme for settling India's constitu-tional position, and irrespective of (a) whether the Declaration was to be issued at once or its issue deferred until after an improvement inthe military situation;(b) whether soundings should be taken of indian political leaders before the Declaration was issued.(2) The draft Declaration, so revised, should be submitted forconsideration by the Special Meeting of the WarCabinet to be held at 12 noon on Monday, the 9th March.(3) A further Meeting of all Ministers of Cabinet rank wouldbe held on Tuesday, the 10th March, at 12 noon.Great George Street, S.W. 1,March 7, 1942. You will, receive by direct repetition views of Cunningham, Glancy and Hallett on points referred to in my telegram 518,2. In order to allow them to see these specific points in perspective-I had to give them the whole picture, namely the full text of draft declaration as it then stood, withvariations given in your telegram 3852 dated March 1st. Inso doing I permitted them to offer personally to me any comments they wished to make on scheme as a whole; Hallettand Glancy have offered general comments but these will nothave been repeated to you.3, Hallett is not unduly alarmed though he isapprehensive of intensifying Congress agrarian agitation inconsequence. However, in view of Commander-in-Chief'sreactions (separately telegraphed), I should be doingwrong in keeping from you Glancy's, which are briefly -(a) contemplated declaration will dumbfound Indian elementswho have hitherto helped, in war and. they will cease to co-operate; (b) nothing will convince Moslems that framing a constitution as contemplated in proposed declaration willnot amount to betrayal; (c) effect on Services will be serious; (d) Sikenclar will probably resign.4. I cannot disregard Governor of the Punjab and onmandex-.in-Chlet4b- vLews and something must be done tomeet them, 5. I am not suggesting that His Majesty's Government can at this stage abandon the essentials of their elan, and I need hardly say it is tar from my desire to mobilise opinionagainst it. But I -do earnestly request you to see. at least^that pledge to minorities is reiterated as an integral partof our new declaration, as suggested in paragraph 2 of my telegram 504-3 of March 2nd, ,6. A promise of local option by itself is no comfort tominority of Moslems in United Provinces and Bihar, and mustrouse gravest apprehensions and bitterest feelings amongstSikhs in the Punjab unless accompanied by specific renewal of our pledge.7. I do not pretend that the mere incorporation of thispledge would solve the Commander-in-Chief's difficulties.Nothing short of the removal of local option (which involves(omission)ing ourselves as guarantors of all the minoritiesin the unification of British India) would do that. If localoption remains the incorporation of minority pledge may (inhis view) at the best prove temporary palliative to such an extent as it might reassure civil opinion amongst -the 4minorities affected. But within the framework of H.M.G.*splan this'is the best that I can suggest,8. The method of insertion that I have proposed is neitherobstructive nor offensive, and is consistent with the basicpolicy of throwing on Indians the responsibility of solvingI their own problem. It is the only hope I can see ofmitigating the effect of communal apprehensions withoutdestroying the basis of the present declaration.9. In view of the Governors' reactions, I an very glad tosee that the word "independence" is not in the latest draft,though I myself had suggested it. Clearly it-ought to be avoided.'
